questions.explanation: The Indian Independence Act 1947 marked the end of British colonial rule and led to the partition of British India into India and Pakistan.

questions.question: Which European explorer first reached India via the Atlantic Ocean?
questions.explanation: Vasco da Gama was the first European explorer to reach India via the Atlantic Ocean, landing in Calicut in 1498.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the Battle of Plassey in 1757?
options: Establishment of British control over Bengal
Defeat of the British by the Marathas
Significant loss for the East India Company
questions.answer: Establishment of British control over Bengal
questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey in 1757 resulted in the establishment of British control over Bengal, largely due to the betrayal of Mir Jafar.

questions.question: Which act allowed the British East India Company to gain administrative rights over Bengal, Bihar, and Odisha?
questions.explanation: The Treaty of Allahabad in 1765 allowed the British East India Company to gain administrative rights over Bengal, Bihar, and Odisha.

questions.question: Which Indian revolutionary was executed for his role in the Kakori Train Robbery of 1925?
questions.explanation: Bhagat Singh was executed for his involvement in the Kakori Train Robbery, an act of revolutionary terrorism aimed at overthrowing British rule.

questions.question: Which leader of the Indian independence movement was known for his role in the establishment of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA)?
questions.explanation: Chandra Shekhar Azad was a prominent leader in the HSRA, an organization dedicated to armed struggle against British rule.

questions.question: Which British official was the Viceroy of India during the Jallianwala Bagh massacre of 1919?
questions.explanation: Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy of India when the Jallianwala Bagh massacre occurred, a tragic event where British troops opened fire on unarmed Indian protesters.

questions.question: In which year was the Indian National Congress founded?
questions.explanation: The Indian National Congress was founded in 1885, marking the beginning of organized political efforts towards Indian self-rule.

questions.question: Which act, passed in 1919, introduced the system of dyarchy in British India?
questions.explanation: The Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms of 1919 introduced the system of dyarchy, dividing governance between elected Indian ministers and appointed British officials.

questions.question: Who was the President of the Indian National Congress during the Lahore session of 1929, where the resolution for complete independence was passed?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru was the President of the Indian National Congress at the Lahore session of 1929, where the resolution for complete independence was adopted.

questions.question: Which Indian leader, a contemporary of Gandhi, advocated for a separate homeland for Muslims leading to the creation of Pakistan?
questions.explanation: Mohammad Ali Jinnah was the leader who advocated for a separate Muslim state, which led to the creation of Pakistan in 1947.

questions.question: Which movement led by Gandhi in the 1930s aimed at breaking the British monopoly on salt production?
questions.explanation: The Civil Disobedience Movement, initiated by Gandhi, aimed to challenge the British monopoly on salt production through non-violent protest.

questions.question: What was the name of the proposed plan in 1940 by the Muslim League that advocated for the creation of separate states for Muslims in British India?
questions.explanation: The Lahore Resolution of 1940 proposed the creation of separate states for Muslims, eventually leading to the establishment of Pakistan.

questions.question: Which act, passed in 1935, granted provincial autonomy and established a federal system in British India?
questions.explanation: The Government of India Act of 1935 granted provincial autonomy and established a federal system in British India, marking a significant political reform.

description: The Constitution of India came into effect on January 26, 1950, and is the supreme law of India.

questions.question: When did the Constitution of India come into effect?
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India came into effect on 26th January 1950, marking the day India became a republic.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Father of the Indian Constitution'?
questions.explanation: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is recognized as the 'Father of the Indian Constitution' for his role in drafting the Constitution.

questions.question: What is the preamble of the Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: The preamble serves as an introduction to the Constitution, outlining its purpose and goals.

questions.question: What does the term 'sovereign' in the Constitution signify?
options: India is part of the British Empire
questions.explanation: 'Sovereign' means that India is an independent nation and is not under the control of any foreign power.

questions.question: How many fundamental rights are guaranteed by the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India guarantees six fundamental rights to its citizens.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution contains fundamental duties?
questions.explanation: Part IVA of the Constitution contains the fundamental duties of Indian citizens.

questions.question: What is the minimum age to become the President of India?
questions.explanation: To be eligible for the office of the President of India, a person must be at least 35 years old.

questions.question: Which body is responsible for interpreting the Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court of India is the highest judicial body responsible for interpreting the Constitution.

questions.question: What is the term of office for the President of India?
questions.explanation: The President of India is elected for a term of 5 years.

questions.question: Which amendment made India a 'Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic'?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment added the words 'Socialist' and 'Secular' to the preamble, describing India as a 'Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic.'

questions.question: Which part of the Constitution deals with the Union and its Territory?
questions.explanation: Part I of the Indian Constitution deals with the Union and its Territory, defining the territorial limits of India.

questions.question: Which Article of the Constitution provides the right to equality?
questions.explanation: Article 14 guarantees the right to equality before the law and equal protection under the law.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Directive Principles of State Policy in the Indian Constitution?
options: To serve as guidelines for the government
questions.answer: To serve as guidelines for the government
questions.explanation: The Directive Principles of State Policy are non-enforceable guidelines for the government to promote social welfare and economic justice.

questions.question: Which article of the Indian Constitution deals with the abolition of untouchability?
questions.explanation: Article 17 of the Indian Constitution abolishes untouchability and forbids its practice in any form.

questions.question: How many schedules does the Indian Constitution originally have?
questions.explanation: The original Constitution of India had 8 schedules, which are lists that categorize and tabulate bureaucratic activity and government policy.

questions.question: What does Article 368 of the Indian Constitution deal with?
questions.explanation: Article 368 provides the procedure for amending the Constitution of India.

questions.question: The concept of 'judicial review' in India is based on which country’s constitution?
questions.explanation: India's concept of 'judicial review' is borrowed from the United States Constitution.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with elections?
questions.explanation: Part XV of the Constitution deals with elections, including the Election Commission and the process of conducting elections in India.

questions.question: Which constitutional amendment lowered the voting age from 21 to 18 years?
questions.explanation: The 61st Amendment Act of 1988 lowered the voting age for elections to the Lok Sabha and Legislative Assemblies from 21 to 18 years.

questions.question: Under which article can the President of India proclaim a national emergency?
questions.explanation: Article 352 of the Indian Constitution grants the President the power to proclaim a national emergency in the event of war, external aggression, or armed rebellion.

questions.question: Which amendment is often referred to as the 'mini-Constitution' due to its wide-ranging changes?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment, passed in 1976, made extensive changes to the Constitution and is often referred to as the 'mini-Constitution.'

questions.question: Which article of the Constitution provides for the right to constitutional remedies?
questions.explanation: Article 32 guarantees the right to constitutional remedies, enabling citizens to approach the Supreme Court if their rights are violated.

questions.question: Which schedule of the Constitution deals with the allocation of seats in the Rajya Sabha to states and union territories?
questions.explanation: The Fourth Schedule of the Indian Constitution deals with the allocation of seats in the Rajya Sabha to the states and union territories.

questions.question: In which case did the Supreme Court of India introduce the concept of 'basic structure' of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The concept of the 'basic structure' was introduced by the Supreme Court in the Keshavananda Bharati Case (1973), restricting the power of Parliament to amend certain fundamental aspects of the Constitution.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with Panchayati Raj?
questions.explanation: Part IX of the Constitution contains provisions related to the Panchayati Raj system in India.

questions.question: Which article of the Indian Constitution deals with the power of the President to consult the Supreme Court?
questions.explanation: Article 143 gives the President of India the power to seek the Supreme Court's opinion on any question of law or fact.

questions.question: Which constitutional amendment introduced the concept of cooperative societies?
questions.explanation: The 97th Amendment introduced provisions for cooperative societies into the Constitution, recognizing their importance in promoting economic and social development.

questions.question: Which article provides for the establishment of a Finance Commission in India?
questions.explanation: Article 280 of the Constitution provides for the establishment of a Finance Commission to recommend the distribution of financial resources between the Union and the states.

questions.question: Which amendment to the Constitution limited the power of judicial review during emergencies?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment limited the power of judicial review by the courts during emergencies, though some of these provisions were later repealed by the 44th Amendment.

questions.question: Under which article does the President of India have the power to declare a financial emergency?
questions.explanation: Article 360 of the Indian Constitution empowers the President to declare a financial emergency if there is a threat to the financial stability or credit of India.

description: Post-Independence Politics shaped modern India with key events like the Green Revolution, Emergency, and liberalization.

questions.question: Who was the first Prime Minister of independent India?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru became the first Prime Minister of India after independence in 1947.

questions.question: Which political party led India after independence?
questions.explanation: The Indian National Congress played a crucial role in the independence movement and led the country after 1947.

questions.question: Who was the first President of independent India?
questions.explanation: Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the first President of independent India, serving from 1950 to 1962.

questions.question: Which state was the first to be created on a linguistic basis after independence?
questions.explanation: Andhra Pradesh was the first state to be created on a linguistic basis in 1953.

questions.question: In which year was the Republic of India formally established?
questions.explanation: India became a republic on 26th January 1950 with the adoption of the Constitution.

questions.question: Which leader is associated with the Green Revolution in India?
questions.explanation: M.S. Swaminathan is known as the father of the Green Revolution in India, which increased agricultural productivity.

questions.question: Which Prime Minister initiated the policy of economic liberalization in 1991?
questions.explanation: P.V. Narasimha Rao's government introduced economic liberalization in 1991, leading to major economic reforms.

questions.question: Who succeeded Jawaharlal Nehru as the second Prime Minister of India?
questions.explanation: Lal Bahadur Shastri succeeded Nehru as the second Prime Minister of India in 1964.

questions.question: Which event led to the declaration of emergency in India in 1975?
questions.explanation: The emergency was declared after the Allahabad High Court found Indira Gandhi guilty of electoral malpractices.

questions.question: Which Indian Prime Minister gave the slogan 'Garibi Hatao' (Remove Poverty)?
questions.explanation: Indira Gandhi gave the slogan 'Garibi Hatao' during the 1971 general elections.

questions.question: Which Prime Minister signed the Shimla Agreement with Pakistan in 1972?
questions.explanation: Indira Gandhi signed the Shimla Agreement with Pakistan in 1972 to maintain peace after the 1971 war.

questions.question: In which year did India conduct its first nuclear test, known as 'Smiling Buddha'?
questions.explanation: India conducted its first successful nuclear test at Pokhran in 1974, codenamed 'Smiling Buddha.'

questions.question: Who was the first non-Congress Prime Minister of India?
questions.explanation: Morarji Desai became the first non-Congress Prime Minister of India in 1977 after the Emergency.

questions.question: Which constitutional amendment is related to the Panchayati Raj Institutions?
questions.explanation: The 73rd Amendment Act of 1992 introduced the Panchayati Raj system in India, promoting decentralized governance.

questions.question: Which Indian Prime Minister initiated the Nationalization of Banks in 1969?
questions.explanation: Indira Gandhi initiated the nationalization of 14 major banks in 1969 to extend credit to rural areas and industries.

questions.question: Which Indian Prime Minister is known for the 'Look East Policy' to improve relations with Southeast Asia?
questions.explanation: P.V. Narasimha Rao introduced the 'Look East Policy' to strengthen India’s relations with Southeast Asia.

questions.question: Which Prime Minister was assassinated in 1991 during an election campaign?
questions.explanation: Rajiv Gandhi was assassinated in 1991 by the LTTE during an election rally in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which political party was founded by Kanshi Ram, focusing on Dalit rights?
questions.explanation: Kanshi Ram founded the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) in 1984, focusing on the rights and upliftment of Dalits.

questions.question: Which act was passed in 2005 to promote transparency and accountability in governance?
questions.explanation: The Right to Information (RTI) Act, 2005, empowers citizens to seek information from government bodies, promoting transparency.

questions.question: Who led the first coalition government in India at the Centre in 1977?
questions.explanation: Morarji Desai led the first non-Congress coalition government in India after the 1977 general elections.

questions.question: Which constitutional amendment limited the power of the judiciary during the Emergency?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment, passed during the Emergency in 1976, limited the power of judicial review by courts.

questions.question: In which year did India pass the Anti-Defection Law to prevent political defections?
questions.explanation: The Anti-Defection Law was passed in 1985 to prevent political defections by legislators.

questions.question: Which movement led by Jayaprakash Narayan in 1974 contributed to the declaration of Emergency?
questions.explanation: The 'Total Revolution' movement led by Jayaprakash Narayan in 1974 opposed corruption and called for reforms, contributing to the political environment that led to the Emergency.

questions.question: Which Prime Minister is known for conducting the second nuclear test series, 'Operation Shakti,' in 1998?
questions.explanation: Atal Bihari Vajpayee's government conducted the second nuclear tests, known as 'Operation Shakti,' at Pokhran in 1998.

questions.question: In which year was the Mandal Commission report implemented, leading to widespread protests?
questions.explanation: The Mandal Commission report, recommending reservations for OBCs, was implemented in 1990, leading to widespread protests.

questions.question: Which constitutional article was abrogated in 2019, revoking the special status of Jammu & Kashmir?
questions.explanation: Article 370, granting special status to Jammu & Kashmir, was abrogated by the Indian government in 2019.

questions.question: Who was the first Chief Election Commissioner of India after independence?
questions.explanation: Sukumar Sen was the first Chief Election Commissioner of India, overseeing the first general elections in 1952.

questions.question: Which agreement between India and Sri Lanka in 1987 sought to resolve the Tamil issue?
questions.explanation: The Indo-Sri Lanka Accord was signed in 1987 between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and President J.R. Jayewardene to resolve the Tamil issue in Sri Lanka.

questions.question: Which Indian Prime Minister introduced the 'Panchsheel Agreement' with China in 1954?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru introduced the 'Panchsheel Agreement' with China in 1954 to promote peaceful coexistence between nations.

questions.question: Which political party emerged from the split in Congress in 1969, led by Indira Gandhi?
questions.explanation: Congress (I), led by Indira Gandhi, emerged from the 1969 split in the Indian National Congress, marking a major political realignment.
